citation.article-title: Clostridium asparagiforme sp. nov., isolated from a human faecal sample.

p.s: Description of Clostridium asparagiforme sp. nov.
C. asparagiforme (as.pa.ra.gi.for’ me. L. masc.n. asparagus asparagus, L. neut. suffix -forme having the shape of, N.L. neut. adj. asparagiforme having the shape of asparagus stems)
Consists of anaerobic, Gram-positive, sporulating rods, which are approximately 0.6–0.8 μm wide and 2.3–5.0 μm long.
On Columbia blood agar, non-haemolytic, slightly raised, white, and irregular colonies with a diameter of 2–2.5 mm are formed after 48 h at 37 °C.
The organism forms acetate, lactate and ethanol as major products and hydrogen and formate as minor products from glucose fermentation.
The isolate hydrolyses glucose, l-tryptophan and the p-nitrophenyl derivatives of β-d-galactopyranoside, α-d-galactopyranoside, β-d-glucouronide, α-d-glucopyranoside and α-l-fucopyranoside.
Using the API-ZYM system, activity was detected for esterase, acid phosphatase, esterase lipase, napthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, β-glucuronidase and α-glucuronidase.
The long-chain cellular fatty acids of the isolate consist primarily of 18:1 cis9 DMA (15.23%), 16:0 (14.84%), 16:1 cis9 DMA (13.76%), 16:0 DMA (8.14%), 17:1 cis8 (6.92%).
The DNA G+C content of C. asparagiforme is 53 mol%.
The GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ accession number for the 16S rRNA gene sequence of C. asparagiforme is AJ582080.
